sn47.51-62:3.1: 51–​62 Twelve Discourses on the Ganges River, etc.
sn47.51-62:4.1: “Mendicants, the Ganges river slants, slopes, and inclines to the east.
sn47.51-62:4.2: In the same way, a mendicant who develops the four kinds of mindfulness meditation slants, slopes, and inclines to extinguishment.
sn47.51-62:5.1: And how does a mendicant who develops the four kinds of mindfulness meditation slant, slope, and incline to extinguishment?
sn47.51-62:5.2: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.51-62:5.3: They meditate by observing an aspect of feelings …
sn47.51-62:5.5: principles, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.51-62:5.6: That’s how a mendicant who develops the four kinds of mindfulness meditation slants, slopes, and inclines to extinguishment.” (To be expanded as follows:)
sn47.51-62:7.1: Six on slanting to the east,
sn47.51-62:7.2: and six on slanting to the ocean;
sn47.51-62:7.4: and that’s how this chapter is recited.
